title: Data Viz
text:
We do a lot of data viz at R for the Rest of Us. Most of the work we do is for general audiences, or at least for folks not super familiar with data. As a result, our data viz tends to look more like data viz seen in the media rather than like that seen in, say, academia.
When making data viz for R for the Rest of Us, we abide by four main principles:

Highlight
Declutter
Explain
Sparkle

I talk about these principles in a video I made for the Going Deeper with R course.




What this means in practice is the following:
We highlight important findings using descriptive titles that show what‚Äôs happening with the data. Things like ‚Äú90% of people do X‚Äù rather than ‚ÄúPercent of people who do X.‚Äù The rationale for this is laid out in this article by Stephanie Everegreen.
We declutter our charts by removing unnecessary elements. Here‚Äôs an example of such a chart. Note that we have removed most grid lines, and the y axis title. This makes the data easier to read and make sense of.

We explain by using annotations where possible.
We make our charts sparkle by using custom fonts and custom themes. We have an internal custom theme in the rfortherestofus package.





But more often, we create a custom theme for clients we work with. This involves using their fonts and colors. In cases where clients have branding guidelines, we use those. If not, we get colors and fonts from their website and use them.

title: Curriculum
text:
Sections
R for the Rest of Us courses are broken up into lessons and sections. Related lessons should be combined into sections. For example, my Fundamentals of R course has sections on RMarkdown, Data Wrangling and Analysis, and Data Visualization.

title: Curriculum
text:
Lessons
The number of lessons varies by course. However, as a general rule, core courses tend to be longer (between 30 and 40 lessons) while topics courses tend to be shorter (15 to 30 lessons).
Each lesson should cover one distinct topic. Each lesson within a section should be short and focus on a single topic. As you‚Äôre making your materials, if you think that a video demonstrating the concept will go beyond 10 minutes or so, consider breaking it into multiple lessons.
Each lesson has the following sections:

Video overview
Your Turn exercise (some lessons don‚Äôt lend themselves to this and don‚Äôt have an exercise)
Code and video solutions (only if there is a Your Turn)
Learn More section with links to resources on that topic

Here‚Äôs what it looks like (you can see this lesson here).

Lessons will typically start with your face on camera, then go to full screen of your slides/RStudio. Here‚Äôs an example.

text:
Materials
The materials for each courses lives in a GitHub repo on the R for the Rest of Us organization account. David will create this and add you to the repo.

Slides

There is a custom template to use to make slides in the R for the Rest of Us style. You can access this by installing the rfortherestofus package using the following code:

title: Terms
text: Here are the legal and financial terms that I typically use when working with course instructors (this is the broad overview; you will receive a full contract with this all spelled out). I‚Äôm flexible and happy to work with you to come up with a solution that meets both of our needs.

title: Terms
text:
Compensation
I pay an advance to the course creator of $500, half on signing the contract to work together, and the other half when the course is released.
Revenue for the courses is split 60/40 (60% for R for the Rest of Us, 40% for the course creator). I pay any royalties owed to the course creator on a quarterly basis.

title: Terms
text:
Ownership
All videos are owned by R for the Rest of Us. All non-video materials will be made freely available on the R for the Rest of Us organization GitHub using a CC-BY-SA-4.0 License.

title: Terms
text:
Exclusivity
The instructor agrees not to create a course that covers the same topic on another online platform for at least 12 months from the release of this course.

title: Terms
text:
Agreement Expiration
These terms remain in effect for one year after the course is released. After that, David and the instructor will discuss any possible changes to the terms.

text:
Plugins
The website uses many plugins. Here are some of the most important and less obvious ones.
AffiliateWP enables us to have affiliates who are paid for referring customers (not currently using this)
BuddyBoss Platform + BuddyBoss Platform Pro hosts groups and forums for cohort-based courses
ConvertKit allows me to do things like apply a tag to a customer whenever they purchase a course

LearnDash is probably the most important plugin. It is what we use to manage all courses. BuddyBoss integrates with it, making the course pages even more attractive. The one thing to note with LearnDash is that we use WooCommerce for signup and just use LearnDash itself for the course stuff.

Uncanny Automator + Uncanny Automator Pro allow us to automate various things (e.g.¬†sending notifications on new comments to Twist)
WooCommerce is how we handle all ecommerce on the site. We also use add-on Woo plugins:

WooCommerce Product Vendors allows us to track commissions for course instructors

title: Welcome
text: Welcome! You are reading an in-progress version of the R for the Rest of Us handbook.

title: Welcome
text:
Mission
The goal of R for the Rest of Us is to help people use R to do good in the world.

title: Welcome
text:
Our Work
The business has two main arms: education and consulting.

Education
On the education side, we offer:

Self-paced and cohort-based courses
In-person public workshops
Custom training for organizations



Consulting
On the consulting side, we do a range of projects. Almost all of them involve some combination of:

Data visualization
Using R to improve workflows
Automating reporting (especially with parameterized reporting)

title: Welcome
text:
Roadmap
As a business that does both education and consulting work, the R for the Rest of Us roadmap is guided by internal and external factors. We do our best to be thoughtful about future directions we think are useful based on customer feedback while also leaving space to adjust based on new information.

title: Welcome
section: A Business with a Social Conscience
text:
A Business with a Social Conscience
R for the Rest of Us is not just a money-making enterprise. I also want it to be a business with a social conscience. We put this into practice by:

Highlighting important issues in the work we do (e.g.¬†the types of projects we work on)
Making it possible for people of various means to learn R (through parity purchasing power and scholarships)
Donating a portion of revenue to organizations working for social justice

title: Welcome
text:
People
R for the Rest of Us is headed by David Keyes. I‚Äôve outlined my role in David‚Äôs Responsibilities.
Current consultants include Charlie Hadley, Thomas Vroylandt, Cara Thompson, Crystal Lewis, and Joscelin Rocha-Hidalgo. Other consultants are brought in for individual projects.

text:
The best description of branding that I‚Äôve read is from Gumroad:

With this persona in mind, I‚Äôve intentionally tried to make the R for the Rest of Us personality:

Logo, colors, typography
When most people think of branding, this is what they‚Äôre asking about. You can find the various logos, colors, and typography that I use on Canva.

title: Social Media
text:
Social media is the main marketing strategy to help people become aware of R for the Rest of Us. The main platform we use is Twitter, as that‚Äôs where most R users are. We also market through LinkedIn.
All social media is designed not so much to sell directly (though we do a bit of this), but to get people on the R for the Rest of Us email list (see Email Marketing). Once they are on that list, we attempt to educate them and convince them to buy products form us.

title: Social Media
text:
Twitter
Active R users are on Twitter. We try to reach them not so much to sell to them directly (though this does sometimes happen), but more to have them connect people looking to learn R (who currently users are likely to know) with R for the Rest of Us.

We find R content produced by others and tweet it out on weekdays at 6am using Buffer.
We share R for the Rest of Us content on Thursdays at 9am. I‚Äôve done this by using a Zapier integration that connects Airtable to Buffer.
We also regularly share promotional material (i.e.¬†links directly to a course) using Buffer or Typefully (if we want to schedule a thread). We don‚Äôt currently have a schedule for this, but probably should.

LinkedIn
In the first half of 2022, we set up content to go out to LinkedIn. We should continue to do this.

title: Recording
text: Once you‚Äôve developed the course curriculum, you‚Äôre ready to record. Here are some tips to help you do so successfully.

title: Recording
text:
Defaults
Please use defaults when you teach. This means having your RStudio set up to look like it would for a student. If you move your panels around, for example, please revert to the default when recording lessons.
Please also use default fonts while you are teaching. Pretty as they are, please don‚Äôt use fonts like Fira Code, as the differences in how they render the assignment operator, for example, can be confusing for newbies.

title: Recording
text:
Code Style
Please follow the tidyverse style guide as closely as possible. The most important thing is to have code that is easy to read for new learners. You‚Äôre welcome to use the styler package to format your code.

title: Recording
text:
Recording Videos
For those on Mac or Windows, recording happens with Descript. David will set you up with a license so you can use it.

Getting Ready to Record
This image from Egghead is an accurate representation of what goes into making videos.

Before you record there are several things to take into consideration.
Please tidy whatever portion of your workspace will show in the background of videos. No need to go 100% Marie Kondo, but please try to keep it neat. Not only does it look more professional, it also encourages people to focus on what you‚Äôre teaching, not whatever random object is on your bookshelf.
Please use an external microphone. Try to keep it as close to you as possible, though I generally try to keep it off screen.
Adjust your screen resolution. Adjusting your screen resolution makes your code much easier to read.
Working on a Mac, I go to Settings > Displays and select 1024 x 576 (HiDPI). As Egghead explains about HiDPI:

HiDPI mode‚Äîalso known broadly as DPI scaling, or Retina display on Macs‚Äîdoubles each pixel, allowing for highly readable text on very high-resolution screens.

There are some instructions for doing the same thing on Windows here.
Please hit the top menu bar when you record. Please go into full screen mode in RStudio. This hides your top menu bar and keeps the focus on your code.

Please use an external webcam. They tend to be higher quality than built-in ones.
If you are interested in learning more tips about high-quality screencasting, this guide from Egghead is helpful.


Recording Lessons in Descript
You will record videos using Descript. It‚Äôs a great tool and has extensive documentation.
Please create a new project for each lesson. Use the blue new project button, not the classic project option.

Here‚Äôs how to record a lesson.



You can re-record as much as you‚Äôd like. It‚Äôs helpful if you can delete bad takes that you don‚Äôt want included. Just highlight the text and hit delete.

title: Editing
text:
After the instructor records videos on Descript, David and team edit them.
Most lessons will have the following structure:

Intro sting
Full video on instructor as they introduce topic
Full screen on slides/RSutdio as instructor presents lesson
Full screen on Your Turn section
Outro sting

After editing each video, the intro and outro animation should be added.

title: Editing
text:
Descript Tips
The easiest way to start out is to remove word gaps. I do this for any gaps greater than 1 second. This ensures that any times the instructor paused to gather their thoughts etc, those blank spaces are removed.
Leave 0.25 seconds gaps between clips where the instructor is on camera and clips where they‚Äôre showing their screen.
When there are two back-to-back clips of the speaker on camera, do a 0.5 second crossfade so the jump isn‚Äôt too abrupt.
Where appropriate, use stock videos/photos on Descript to highlight a concept.
You can zoom into sections of the screen on Descript. For example, in a video showing the pieces of RStudio, it may make sense to zoom into each one as I discuss it. Make zooms quicker ‚Äî around 1 second.
Where appropriate, use callout boxes, arrows, and text to draw the learner‚Äôs attention to a specific area of the screen (for example, when the instructor says ‚Äúyou can see here‚Ä¶‚Äù). Use the R for the Rest of Us oragne color (#ff7400) consistently when adding these attention grabbers.

title: Editing
text:
Sound
Sound levels should be fairly consistent assuming recording conditions remain consistent. However, if necessary you can auto-level clips.
Studio sound: TODO figure out if we should use it

title: Editing
text:
Export
There are two ways to export videos:

Exporting directly
Publishing and then downloading

It is best to do the second option, as it is much quicker. Simply hit publish in the top right. Once the project is published, you can then hit the download button. If you make changes to the project, simply hit Update and then re-download.

title: Project Management
text:
Create a GitHub repo (set to private unless the client is ok with it being public):

Use the README to lay out the overall project scope, deliverables, etc.
Use issues to manage code-related questions at a granular level.

title: Project Management
text:
Client Communication
The most important thing we can do is communicate effectively and regularly. This means getting back to clients within 24 hours.
The type of communication we use with clients depends on the client.

If clients are comfortable working in GtiHub and we decide it is appropriate to have them collaborate on GitHub, feel free to add them to the repo.
If they don‚Äôt want to work in GitHub (most don‚Äôt), email is generally best.

We should email clients each week to give them an overall update on progress and see if they have any questions.

title: Project Management
text:
Schedule
For each client, we create a file that outlines the milestones in the project and the tasks to be done. This is created as a .qmd file and then rendered to HTML. We then set up Netlify to host the HTML file and share the link with the client. Here is an example document.

The schedule should be updated each week when we email the client an update.

title: Finances
text:
R for the Rest of Us finances are managed using QuickBooks.
We do the following tasks in the first week of each month:
Categorize and approve all expenses in QuickBooks: If unclear on category, first look at previous months. If still unclear, ask David.
Send invoices to clients with QuickBooks: Time should be checked on Toggl reports and an invoice should be generated for each client. Some projects are billed hourly while others are billed at a flat rate (details are in the associated Todoist tasks).
Pay contractors with Gusto: All contractors will submit an invoice each month. They are then paid with Gusto.

title: Finances
text:
Quarterly Tasks
Each quarter we reconcile accounts in QuickBooks. This is done by getting statements from both Advantis Credit Union and Mercury and then entering balances here. This compares the balances in my bank accounts to those in QuickBooks to make sure everything matches up.
I also pay course instructors each quarter. You can go to the commission report on the website and see which commissions are unpaid. You can total these up for each instructor (they‚Äôre called a vendor on this part of the website) and then pay them through Gusto. Each instructor gets an advance so they only start receiving commissions when they earn more than the advance.

title: Finances
text:
Annual Tasks
We send out 1099s to all contractors by Gusto. I‚Äôve set Gusto up to make sure this happens, but we should check to confirm this in mid-January.

title: Email Automations
text:
Email marketing is the main way that R for the Rest of Us brings in revenue.
All external marketing is designed to get people onto the R for the Rest of Us email list. Once they‚Äôre on the list, we send them regular emails that educate them about R, interspersing emails that attempt to sell them on our offerings.
The specifics of how our email marketing system works comes largely from Brennan Dunn‚Äôs Mastering ConvertKit course. The process gets fairly complicated, but at the highest level, here‚Äôs what it does:
Below are details about how email automations work. Note that sequences aren‚Äôt included because they are generally just called from Visual Automations below.

title: Email Automations
text:
Signup
Here are the signup journeys that users experience on the R for the Rest of Us email list.

Getting Started
If the user gets onto the list by signing up for Getting Started, they get the tag Purchased - Getting Started applied through the WooCommerce-ConvertKit integration.
They then go through the Getting Started - Signup - Automation. This does the following:

Assigns the tag Customer - Course/Workshop
Assigns the tag Customer
Assigns the tag Flag - Calculate Next offer (which sends them through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation)
Assigns the Flag - Remove from Shadow Newsletter tag, which does what it says
Puts them through the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, which sends a set of emails about the course
When they complete the course or the Getting Started - Signup - Sequence, they get pulled to the end and go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation

The Fundamentals - Bridge - Automation pitches people on Fundamentals. It happens in two ways depending on what the user has done so far on Getting Started.

If the user has the Completed - Getting Started tag, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Hot. This goes straight to the pitch for Fundamentals.
If the user has not completed Getting Started, they go into the Fundamentals - Bridge - Cold. This sends them a few emails before pitching them on Fundamentals.

After they go through the bridge sequences, they go into the Fundamentals - Pitch - Automation.

The tag Flag - Pitch Window Open - Fundamentals gets applied. This triggers Zapier to create a personalized coupon on WooCommerce.
The user gets an email on Friday telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.
The tag Completed - Onboarding is applied.
The tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is applied. This triggers the Shadow Newsletter - Automation and adds them to the shadow newsletter.



Other Courses

If they sign up for a course, each Woo products assigns them the appropriate tag (e.g.¬†Purchased - Fundamentals).
Then, they go through a visual automation for each course (e.g.¬†Fundamentals - Signup - Automation)
Then, this automation rule assigns them the tag Flag - New Subscriber.



R in 3 Months

If they sign up for R in 3, WooCommerce assigns them the tag Purchased - R in 3 Months.
Then, they go through this visual automation, which sends them an email that welcomes them. All other communication about R in 3 Months happens directly via Gmail.



Newsletter
If someone signs up for the newsletter using this form, the following happens:

The Flag - New Subscriber tag is added to them through this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag puts them into the Global - Welcome - Sequence using this automation rule

The Flag - New Subscriber tag being added puts them onto the New Subscriber - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation and Function - Tag Custom Training/Consulting Clients - Automation
The New Subscriber - Automation moves them through the Function - Calculate Topics vs Core Courses

If they are a custom training/consulting client, they get the Completed - Onboarding and the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tags applied, which moves them onto the shadow newsletter
If they are not a custom training/consulting client, they are moved to the Getting Started - Pitch - Automation (if they haven‚Äôt signed up for it already)

If user signs up for you can do that, it happens with this form.

title: Email Automations
text:
Shadow Newsletter
Any time the tag Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter is added to a user, they go through the Shadow Newsletter - Automation. This does the following:

Removes the Flag - Start Shadow Newsletter tag (so it can be added again)
Checks if they‚Äôve completed part 1 of the shadow newsletter. If not, puts them onto that sequence. If so, moves onto the next part.
Repeats the previous step through each part of the shadow newsletter.

After the user completes each part of the shadow newsletter, they get the tag Locked - Pitched added. This puts them onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation.
New content is constantly added to the last part of the shadow newsletter sequences so that people continually receive emails.

title: Email Automations
text:
Pitching

Calculate Next Offer
Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation calculates the next offer for the user by doing the following:

Runs Function - Calculate Topics vs Core Courses to see what type of course user should be pitched on. That automation adds Flag - Pitch on Topics Courses to those for whom it is appropriate (if they have said they are intermediate/advanced, have said they‚Äôre interested in topics courses, or have been pitched on all core courses).
If user has Flag - Pitch on Topics Courses, the automation looks at which course they‚Äôve yet to have been pitched on. It then adds the next course in the following order as their next_offer custom field: Mapping, Data Cleaning, Inferential Stats.



Move to Pitch
When the user gets put onto Function - Move to Pitch - Automation:

The user gets the Flag - Remove from Shadow Newsletter tag added so they don‚Äôt get newsletter emails while being pitched.
The user goes through the Function - Calculate Next Offer - Automation, which calculates their next offer
Based on the custom field next_offer, the user is put onto a PRODUCT - Pitch - Automation for their next offer.



Self-Paced Course Pitch
All self-paced course pitches follow the same rough pattern as Fundamentals:

The user gets an email on Friday (for some courses it‚Äôs Monday) telling them their personal window is open to purchase Fundamentals.
The user goes through the Fundamentals - Pitch - Sequence, which sends an email every day the next week with info on purchasing Fundamentals.

text:
Segmentation
Users are segmented by asking questions in the survey on this page:

How would you describe your level of expertise with R?
Why do you want to learn R (or, if you already use it, learn more)?
What has stopped you from learning R (or learning more R if you already use it)?
What‚Äôs your main tool for working with data?
How big is the organization you work in?
What type of courses are you interested in?

Data submitted through this form gets piped back to ConvertKit using Zapier.
New users also get added to the Global - Profiling - Sequence through the New Subscriber - Automation. This sequences sends them an email each Sunday asking them one of the questions above.

title: Overview
text:
R for the Rest of Us has multiple self-paced online courses. The core courses (i.e.¬†for those just learning R) are taught by David. There are also topics courses taught by others.
These are instructions for making an R for the Rest of Us online course. The overall process from start to finish looks something like this:

title: Overview
text:
Intro Call

Discuss course idea
Go over legal and financial terms
Discuss timing
Confirm instructor has access to external camera and mic
Share course-making instructions (i.e.¬†what you‚Äôre looking at)

title: Overview
text:
Terms

David + instructor sign contract
David pays 50% of advance to instructor

title: Overview
text:
Curriculum

David explains how lessons work (e.g.¬†video, your turn, solutions, learn more)
David explains how to create course outline
David shares rfortherestofus package to be used for the custom xaringan template
Instructor develops slides
David approves slides

title: Overview
text:
Recording

David sets up shared Google Drive folder for raw videos
Instructor records single test video
David approves test video
Instructor records all lesson and solutions videos

title: Overview
text:
Production

David edits videos
David has transcripts created for all videos
David puts videos and related materials on website
Instructor reviews and approves videos and course materials

title: Overview
text:
Marketing

David makes course sales page
David develops launch email sequence
David puts together social media launch

title: Overview
text:
Course Launch!

Email goes out to list announcing that course is live

title: Overview
text:
Our basic approach to marketing is simple:

Don‚Äôt market, educate.

By educating, we show people what R is and what you can do with it. Once they appreciate these things, they‚Äôre more likely to want to learn R themselves or to hire us to help them do something with it.

title: Communication
text:
As a fully remote company, we try to communicate by writing as much as possible. Doing so has many benefits:

It forces us to clarify our thinking
It provides a record of decisions for those who may join things midstream
It allows people to work on their own time without feeling the need to join live calls etc

Internal communication happens, as much as possible, in Twist. There are several channels:

Consulting
Course Questions
Courses
General
Orders (all paid course orders go through here)
R in 3 Months
Training

Within each channel, we typically use one thread per project (sometimes more depending on its complexity).
Other places internal communication happens include:

GitHub for discussion of specific issues on code-based projects
Todoist comments for questions on specific tasks to be done
